SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Follow-up of chronic problems. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Mr. Brian Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow- up of his Chronic problems. It has been a little while since I have seen the patient. The patient reports that he feels out of sorts lately. He does not know if it is the change in the seasons or not, but he feels that he is just tired and fatigued. He notes that he has been doing a lot of projects around the house and on his own. He also notes that they began construction on his kitchen over labor day weekend, and it was hard to cook or prepare meals so they ate out a lot, and not always the best food out. He endorses some weight gain, as well as bloating. He denies any fever, chills, or dyspnea on exertion. Regarding his shortness of breath, he notes that that can also be caused by fluid in his lungs. He states that if he is ex- exerting any energy, he will feel it at that point. Mr. Smith also endorses slight cramps in his chest, that seems to go away after about an hour after he first feels it. He attributes this to the change of seasons. He is not experiencing any other symptoms of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or lightheadedness. He continues to take his medications, as noted above. The Patient has been compliant with his medications and is doing well at this time. In regards to his congestive Heart failure, he states that he was doing well for the most part of the past year, but it has been chaotic with renovations and he is concerned with gaining weight. He has been watching his diet and has increased his Lasix to 80 mg once a day. He will continue to monitor his blood pressures at home, and report them to me in the patient portal if they are getting elevated. Thepatient denies any fevers or chills. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. • Respiratory: Endorses cough. • Musculoskeletal: Positive weight gain. • Neurological: Positive nausea, dizziness. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 • Constitutional: Negative for fever. • Neck: 1+ pitting edema. Bilateral jugular venous distention to about 8 cm. • Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally. 

RESULTS

 Chest x-ray: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, which we have heard in the past. Cardiovascular echocardiogram: 45%. leaky valve, mitral regurgitation. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Mr.Brian Smith is an 58- year-oldmale with a history of congestiveHeart failure and Hypertension, who present today for a follow-upof his chronic problems, congestiveheart failure. Congestive heart Failure. • Medical Reasoning: He is retaining fluid. • Additional Testing: We will order a repeat echocoboardiogram. • Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to increase his lasix to80 mg once daily. High blood pressure. • medical Reasoning; He is managing this well. – Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right knee pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee Pain. She states she fell a couple of days ago and twisted her right knee as she was trying to change a light bulb. She has been putting ice on it and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She rates her pain level as high. She is taking Digoxin, which she begins with a D. Her past surgical history is significant for a nose job. 

EXAM

 Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee over the lateral aspect of the medial meniscus area. There is no pain with flexion or extension, but there is a little bit of tenderness when she flexes her knee with valgus stressing on her leg. 

RESULTS

 X-rays of the left knee shows no obvious signs of fracture. Mild effusion about the medial aspect. 

IMPRESSION

 right knee pain, right knee. 

PLAN

 At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we treat the patient conservatively. She will take Motrin, 800 mg, every 6 hours as needed. We will also refer her to crutches and a crutch. She should follow up with me in 1 week for repeat imaging. All questions were answered. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up in 1 Week.

He states he thought he heard a pop at the time and had to lie down for approximately hour before it relieved the pain. His back has been stiff since that time. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat on the spot, but it did not seem to help. He denies any numbness or tingling in his legs. He endorses pain with flexion and extension of his back. On his back exam, he does have some pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. He reports negative straight leg raise.

 • Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or changes in appetite. • Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and dyspnea on exertion. • Musculoskeletal: Endorse lower back pain and stiffness.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Iron deficiency anemia. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Christina cooper is a 65-year-old female who was referred by Diane Nelson for a long-standing iron deficiencyanemia. She was diagnosed in 12/2019 for fatigue, fever, and chills. She has been feeling fatigued often during the day and even feverish with chills at times. When she tries to be active she feels like she can not catch her breath and feels like he is wheezing. She also has been noting some chilling sensations. She denies any headaches. The patient has a history of heavy periods until she had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her followup blood work on 01/20/20 was revealed a low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, and normal iron labs, although ferritin was low. Her last colonoscopy was about 5 to 6 years ago and was relatively normal. She did not have any polyps. Ms. cooper is taking ferrous sulfate, 300 mg by mouth, 500 mg twice daily. She is not taking any supplements such as iron or vitamin B12 at this time. I have asked her to continue each dose with vitamin C found in orange juice, twice daily for the next 12 weeks. She should then recheck her blood work in about 8-12 weeks. If her bloodwork is normal, we will consider a capsule endoscopy or Colonoscopy. If this is inconclusive, we may need to consider an Egd and colonoscopic. She can call us if she has any questions or worsening symptoms. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up in 10 years. She will start taking iron pills with orange juice for about 8 to 12 weeks to help absorb the iron. If she is still anemic at that time, she will see a hematologist. Call us with any concerns or questions. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 SYSTEMSurgical history: Denies chest pain, dyspnea, sleep apnea, or use oxygen at night. 

PAST HISTORY

 Medical Hypothyroidism. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

 Ms. Cooper is a pleasant 65- year- old female who is a new patient who was diagnosed with iron deficiencyAnemia. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 Patient reports history of iron deficiency Anemia since she was 13 years old. she has been anemic since then and has been taking iron supplementation since then. She does have a history OF heavy periods, but her periods are no longer an issue. 

MEDICATIONS

 Patient reports taking vitamin C 25 mg tablets twice daily, in the morning and in the evening. She no longer takes iron supplements. 

RESULTS

 Follow-up hemoglobin A1c, stable hemoglobin B12, and iron labs were normal, althoughferritin is low. Referral to hematologists provided. 

ASSESSMENT

 • Iron deficiency Anemic. 

PLAN

 Ms. Collins is a 67-year -old female, female who presents today for an evaluation of iron deficient anemia, long-term. Her recent blood work was revealed to be low hemoglucose, stable Hematocritic, and Normal iron labs. A referral was sent to her hematology for further evaluation with possible anemia or gastrointestinal bleeding. She plans to follow up with him in 10 Years. We will plan for an EDS and colonoscope to assess for potential sources of anemia and/or gastrointestinal bleed. If these tests are normal, she can proceed with a capsule Endoscopy, but if they are inconclusive we may consider a colonoscopies. I recommended a bowel prep to clean out her bowels ahead of time. In addition, the patient should start taking Iron C with Orange Juice, 25 mg once daily for approximately 8- 12 weeks, to help absorption. This should resolve her symptoms. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Esophagitis.

 Betty Hill is a new patient with a referral from the emergency room of esophagism. Her symptoms occurred 3 months ago, but she has not had any chest pain since that time. The patient reports that she was going through a really stressful job transition at the time of the pain. She states that she did not have any heartburn or indigestion at that time, so she does not know what that feels like. The pain was located in the center of her chest, right behind her breastbone. She notes that she tolerated the pain for 4 days, but then went to the Emergency room because nothing she did relieved it. They ran an EKG, ran a blood test, and everything was normal. She denies any prior episodes of chest pain. Ms. Hill suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from her musculoskeletal etiologies. She has a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia. She is trying to lose weight and has been asymptomatic for the past 3 months. The chest pain and swallowing problem got better about 3 days after she visited the Emergency Room. She no longer has difficulty swallowing. Her weight has been normal. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion. • Gastrointestinal: Endorses abdominal pain and tenderness. Denies heartburn. • Genitourinary: Endorse dyspepsia. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 • Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. • Abdomen: Mild tenderness to palpation. • Musculoskeleton: Normal strength and tone. No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. 

RESULTS

 Electrocardiogram is normal. X-ray of the esophagus is also normal. Normal gait. Bowel movements are normal.

Her x-rays of her esophages were normal, as was her normal gait today. • Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. • Additional Testing: We discussed the possibility of an Egd or upper endoscopy to take a look at her Esophagus and stomach. CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Smith-Magenis syndrome. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Katherine Smith is a 22-month-old female, a twin, who presents for screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. She is a well-nourished female who is slightly fussy when examined. She used to only drink milk, but was told to take her off dairy milk. She has seen an allergist, and also a neurologist, who diagnosed her with this syndrome because she still does not walk and she was not sitting by herself a year old. She does have a GI doctor because she has reflex really bad. She also had a dietician who told her to take herself off cow’s milk, which she did. She currently is in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She will start speech therapy within the next couple of weeks. The family lives in Dallas, so her follow-up should be at the town center location. She seems to pee a lot, and it feels like she drinks a lot. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or changes in appetite. • Musculoskeletal: Endorses bilateral lower extremity hypotonia. • Neurological: Endorse reflex pain. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 • Integumentary: Eyes are small appearing. Nose, Mouth, and Throat • Cardiovascular: Supple without murmurs, gallops, or rubs. • Respiratory: Bilateral shortness of breath. • Gastrointestinal: Normal external female genitalia. 

RESULTS

 Kidney ultrasound. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Katherine Smith- Magenis Syndrome. • Medical Reasoning: Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature. • Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the syndrome in detail today. I encouraged the patient to continue drinking milk, water, and ripple pea protein milk. • Additional Testing: We are going to order a kidney ultrasound for further evaluation. • medical Treatment: We will refer her to an ophthalmologist and an orthopedic for evaluation. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to review her results.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right wrist pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Diana Diaz is a pleasant 29-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began yesterday, when she was walking up and down the stairs while doing her laundry. She slipped and fell and put her arms out to catch herself, but then her wrist started to hurt real bad and it got real swollen. She rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. The patient reports that she has been icing and applying ice to the area. She also uses her ace wrap at home. She denies any numbness or tingling. Her symptoms are localized to the right side of her right wrist, but she can feel the numbness along her left wrist. She is unable to make a fist. She reports that her right thumb is slightly numb to light touch. She attributes her pain to the radial aspect of her wrist. The Patient denies any lower extremity edema. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right thumb spica. Neurological: Denies numbness in the right thumb. 

VITALS

 Blood pressure: 100/70 mmHg. Heart rate: 80 beats a minute. Respiratory rate: 20. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 CV: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. RESPIRATORY: Normal range of movement with right wrist. Pain to abduction, flexion, and extension. Negative for pain on flexion. Positive for pain in the dorsal aspect of the wrist. Denies pain on abduction, pain on extension, or radial deviation. Pain with radial deviation: Yes, it hurts. When pushed on the inside of the right arm, the pain is constant. It is worse on the outside. 

RESULTS

 X-rays of the Right wrist were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal evidence of a colles' fracture. 

ASSESSMENT

 1. Colles’ fracture. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient’s examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her x-rays revealed evidence of what we refer to as a “collar bone fracture”. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively at first. We will provide her with pain medication, 50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours, and a brace for the next 6 weeks. She will also attend physical therapy 3 times per week to assess her wrist for strength. The plan is to proceed with surgical intervention as soon as possible. She should follow up with me in 1 month to check on her progress, sooner if needed. If her symptoms do not improve with the brace, we will consider postponing the operation. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up in 1 1/2 weeks for her surgery. After that, she will stay overnight in the clinic, and will be bracing her right arm for 6 week. After the surgery, she should be able to go home.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

The onset of his pain began 1 week ago, when he slipped and fell down on his property. He denies hearing a pop at the time of the injury, however, he does feel a pop in his knee when he flexes his knee. He states he has been taking ibuprofen for pain. He rates his pain as a 4 out of 10, with 10 being the worst pain he has ever felt. When he is stationary he does not really feel a lot of pain, but if he starts doing some mobility he would say probably a 4 5. The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently taking 20 mg of lisinopril, which he is doing pretty good with. However, his diet has been out of control and he has not been taking his medications regularly. He is going to get a referral to nutrition to try to help him with his diet. He should also reduce his sodium intake to about 20 mg per day. We will keep him on Lisinopril 20 mg twice a day. I want him to ice his knee for 20 minutes at a time for 3 to 4 times a day that should also help with the swelling of his knee and the pain. I also want to get him a referrals to nutrition for help with his blood pressure, which is currently elevated. He will follow up with me in 2 weeks to check on his progress. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Follow-up during neo- agit chemotherapy. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Ms. Veronica Edwards is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage 3 nonsmile cell lung cancer who presents for a follow-upduring neo-agIT chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. molecular testing is pending at this time. Her symptoms include minimal cough, sore throat, and shortness of breath. She reports intermittent sore throat and dry cough. Her cough is persistent and intermittent. She notes that she has been drinking lots of fluids and eating as much as she normally would. She denies any dyspnea on walking. Regarding her fatigue, she reports a little bit. She has been able to tolerate the nausea and fatigue. The patient denies any nausea or vomiting. She is being provided Prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days. She will eat immediately after taking the prednisone. Prescription for lidocaine swish and swallow provided to be used 4 times daily. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss. HENT: Reports cough. Respiratory: Reports minimal cough. Neurological: Positive fatigue. 

VITALS

 All vital signs are within the normal limits. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 Neck - General Examination: No thyromegaly, lymphadenopathy, no cervical lymphadenpathy, or supraclavicular adenopathy. Cardiovascular - Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs. Bilateral lung exam: Some crackles in lungs bilaterally. 

RESULTS

 X-ray of the chest was reviewed today and shows some pneumonitis likely due to cisplestan and radiation. There is also some erythema on the anterior side of her chest, which could be related to the radiation. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Ms.Veronica Edwards is an 53 -year -old female who presents today for follow- up during Neo-Agit chemotherapy She was recently diagnosed with stage3 nonsmile-cell lung cancer. Her x-ray today showed some pneumons and pneumons due to likely cisplastitis. Due to her cough, she is being seen to drink plenty of fluids, as well as her sore throat. Given that her cough is intermittent, we will treat the patient conservatively with a low dose of prednis one 40 mg twice daily for the next 5 days to help reduce the inflammation. She should also continue to take food and fluids, prevent dehydration and any further weight loss, and report to the clinic at her next visit. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 5 days for repeat radiographic imaging.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

The patient was referred by his primary care physician as he has been having problems getting frequent infections. He states that he is used to getting infections in the wintertime and that he feels that his colds will linger for a long time. He notes that his primary cared physician referred him to us due to his low immunoglobin A1c level. He explains that his immunoglobin level was checked as part of a routine physical. He does note that some people with this level tend to get frequent respiratory tract or sinus infections, as well as abdominal infections. Mr. Allen notes that he does not believe that his current infections are more than usual in theWinter. He endorses that his recent physical was normal and adds that his family is healthy.

 The patient reports that he has a history of type 2 diabetes and his family owns a donut shop down at the end of the street. He denies any recent blood transfusion or blood products.

 He reports that He has a family history of immune deficiencies.

 Medical Type 2 diabetes.

 No family history.

 metformin.

 None.

 • iga deficiency.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right-sided abdomen pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Russell Mitchell is a pleasant 67-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right-sided abdominal pain. The onset of his pain began several days ago, when he felt a sharp pain in the right side of his abdomen below his ribs. He was seen by his primary care physician, who ordered a CT scan of the abdomen and referred him to a urologist for further evaluation. The CT scan revealed a 5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. He denies any pain with urination or urination, but notes that his urine sometimes burns a little bit. He does note some darkening of the urine, however. Regarding his pain with vomiting, he denies any nausea or vomiting. He reports that he has been taking Tylenol, but it has not really helped. The patient has a history of kidney stones in the past; his father had kidney stones and he was able to pass them, but this is taking a lot longer. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right side abdomen pain, nausea, and vomiting. Neurological: Denies fever, chills. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 Gastrointestinal: No tenderness to palpation. No evidence of any rebound or guarding. No peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Acute nephrolithiasis or kidney stone. 

PLAN

 I recommend that the patient push fluids to help facilitate urination and peeing to help pass the stone. I will prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. He can continue to alternate that with tylenol. We will give him a strainer that he can use to strain his urine so that we can see it see the stone when it passes. If his symptoms do not improve over the next week, we will discuss further treatment such as lithotripsy. We could also consider a uREteroscopy which is a small telescope small camera used to go up to the urethra and bladder and up into the ureters. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis. 2. Kidney stone, proximal Right ureTER. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination findings and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his CT scan did reveal a 5 mm kidney stone in his right kidney. I has recommended that we treat the patient conservatively with over-the-counter oxycod one 5 mg daily for pain, as needed. He will also be provided with a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis and a urine culture. I want him to contact me if he is having worsening symptoms. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks. If he is still symptomatic at that time, we may need to consider further treatment including lithotrialpsy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right foot ulcer. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Nicholas Taylor is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcers. The onset of his symptoms began 6 days ago, when he first noticed a necrotic wound on his right foot, approximately 2 by 2 centimeters, on the pad of the bottom of the foot around his heel. He later noticed a foul smell and that his dog was also smelling his socks a lot. He called his primary care physician, who started him on antibiotics 6 days later. After 10 days of antibiotics, the wound began to feel pretty good. The patient reports that he has been ambulating on the front part of his foot, however, he has noticed that it has turned black around the outside of the wound. He also notes that he is having difficulty catching his breath when he is walking around the house. He denies any pain at this time. Regarding his diabetes, he reports that his blood sugars have been trending in the 3 to 4 hundreds for the last 2 weeks. He had one spike at one point at 5 or 6 hundred that got his attention. He is going to order a test to check blood supply for this wound. We are going to do a debridement today in the office. We may have to look at different antibiotic therapy. He will continue his antibiotics. We will also continue his medication therapy with antibiotics and possibly some other medications. He should follow up with his endocrinologist in 7 days. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. All questions were answered.
